title: T-Sampling Distribution
question_text:
A study on women’s weights was recently completed.
Twenty randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $21$ randomly selected females from a rural setting. A portion of the results are below:
Two-Sample $T$ for Urban Weights vs. Rural Weights

Describe the sampling distribution of the difference between urban and rural weights.

choices.text:
Shape unable to be determined.
Mean = −2.7
Standard deviation = 1.16

Standard deviation = 3.72

solution:
To describe the sampling distribution of the difference in sample means, we analyze its shape, center, and spread.

The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) states that the sampling distribution of the difference in means will be approximately normal if each sample size is large enough (typically n≥30
) or if the population distributions are normal.

A common mistake is to add the two sample sizes together (i.e., 20+21=41
) and assume that because the total is above 30
or 40
, the sampling distribution is normal. However, this is incorrect because: - The CLT applies to each individual sample separately, not to their combined total. - If either sample is small and comes from a non-normal population, the sampling distribution may not be normal. - Since both sample sizes are under 30
, normality depends entirely on the population distributions, which we do not know.

Thus, the shape of the sampling distribution is unable to be determined.
